ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: zero
none
none.
none.
0 hours

This is a seminar course that is meant to provide students with a survey of interesting areas of focus with CDE and SBS. It seems that its main objective is to get students thinking about what kind of research they would like to pursue and who they should speak to if they are interested in a particular subject. This is accomplished by bringing speakers who are Yale faculty and who conduct their own research to present their work.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: I think it is helpful to understand what is going on the field and what YSPH researchers are working on. I particularly liked the guest speakers.

The seminars were ok - there weren't many of them though. The topics were usually fairly interesting and it seemed like an ok way to spend an hour over lunch. I would have really liked to hear Megan Smith speak though - I wish that lecture hadn't been canceled.
good diversity of topics
Speakers were great, especially Alice Miller and the last one on HIV in MSM
there weren't enough SBS seminars
The seminars were a good introduction to work being done by faculty.

The course is helpful to get a glimpse of how research is conducted in epidemiology and the areas some of the faculty work on. Nevertheless, I would prefer to have the seminars more frequently so as to know more about the research areas of the faculty.

I loved the SBS faculty panel at the beginning of the semester!! It provided me with a general understanding of each faculty member's research focus. Although this info is available online, it was more interesting to hear it directly from them. I also liked that each of them were direct about research/thesis opportunities.I enjoyed the Dean's lecture, but I was really looking forward to Megan Smith's talk. Hopefully, this will be rescheduled for next semester.Although I am SBS, I attended the talk about measurement issues and I loved the speaker!! She gave an interesting talk, but she was also an amazing person that seemed to really care about students.
the food was pretty gross

I think there must be a way to make this seminar more relevant to students. One session was spent having instructors introduce themselves and their specialties, which I felt like could have been done in an email. The lecture with Ally Miller and the Dean's lecture were good and informative. An hour isn't really much time to be introduced to a topic and then have a thoughtful discussion about it, though. It might be more interesting for students to learn what kind of jobs might await students in the SBS concentration and hear from someone in the field. Most presenters are not from school of public health (they were from psychology or law backgrounds). Students in school of public health are rarely exposed to professionals who have only an MPH, which is somewhat discouraging. It seems like we also have to get an MD to do something productive in the field.
Good overview of the department
good
The seminars were very interesting and were a great way to see current research in our Department at YSPH.
The seminars were a good way to bring the SBS group together. Interesting topics were covered and having food there was also a good thing.
Great course - very interesting projects discussed and a great way to know what kind of research is being conducted at YSPH.

Subjects of seminars varied considerably, might have benefitted from a more cohesive structure. Dr. Xiaomei Ma's overview of different topics she performs research on may be a good guide for this. Overall the course did have lots of interesting material and I enjoyed attending.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Becca Levy  She was fine - not particularly dynamic but very nice. I don't feel like I really have an adequate basis on which to judge her but she seems to be smart and committed to the field.
Instructor: Becca Levy  Very good seminar. Meeting the SBS faculty was great
Instructor: Becca Levy  I didn't feel like I had any significant contact with either of the instructors for this course.
Instructor: Becca Levy  no real interaction
Instructor: Becca Levy  I thought Dr. Levy organized a good seminar series.
Instructor: Becca Levy  This instructor did not teach in class this semester.
Instructor: Becca Levy  It is hard to say since we hardly got to listen to her. However,great idea to do the faculty panel.
Instructor: Becca Levy  good
Instructor: Becca Levy  Organized and is quick to respond to student questions and feedback. Selected great speakers and facilitated a great learning environment.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  I don't know who Susan Mayne is.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  awesome!
Instructor: Susan Mayne  I didn't feel like I had any significant contact with either of the instructors for this course.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  lecture on skin cancer was very interesting
Instructor: Susan Mayne  I thought Dr. Mayne organized a good seminar series.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Dr. Mayne presented a very interesting talk about her research. The presentation was clear and well organized.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Great at introducing speakers and asking pertinent questions. I also loved her talk about indoor tanning.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  great
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Organized and dedicated. Always ready to answer questions and did a great job selecting wonderful speakers and pointingout interesting questions at the end of every session.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It is an opportunity to learn about what is currently going on in the field and to connect with other SBS students.
A seminar series on a range of topics in SBS.
Only meets a few times per semester.
I was unable to attend all sessions but the ones I did were very informative.
yes, the guest lecturers were great
I would recommend to students, as it provides an opportunity to learn about faculty projects in YSPH.
This course would be useful for students in CDE/SBS.
I would recommend it, even for second years that do not have to attend. It is a nice break from classes.
Fine-to-interesting. Free lunch is nice but unimpressively repetitive.
I wouldn't recommend the seminar to others, because I don't feel I'm getting much out of it.
Yes. informative and allows you to get an idea as to what is going on in the department. I also like how food is provided.
good and interesting
The talks are interesting and it's a good time just eating and catching up with friends.

This is a survey course about various areas of research with CDE. If you are interested in pursuing a career in research, this is a great way to get a glimpse of what is possible and how to make it happen.
Yes. Minimal work and allows you to hear several interesting, if different, current chronic disease research topics.
